page.title: 18LOCAL HISTORY:FENNY COMPTON.
page.content: The village was called "Contone" in the Domesday Survey,getting its present name in the reign of Henry 3rd.The village lay off the highroads & remained isolated & remote until the digging of the Oxford Canal in 1776, folowed by the London to Birmingham railway in 1852,both giving links to the outer community.In 1779, at the time of the Enclosure Award, there were 35 small landowners,reduced to 8 by 1841, the census year which shows the rural nature of the grid area.Then there were 61 farmworkers,8 joiners, 5 tailors,4 graziers,4 blacksmiths,3 butchers,2 sawyers,1 miller,3 carriers 2 shoemakers,1 bonesetter,1 Rector,a policeman,& a Schoolmaster.Today,the community is of some 6 farmers,with highly mechanised farms,while many people commute to work by car in local towns.There are many old,& few young.
